Graphical abstract The aim of this study was to investigate the correlation between the basic and catalytic properties of brucite and Mg,Al-layered double hydroxides (Mg,Al-LDHs) in the reaction of propylene oxide with methanol. The basic properties of the solids were investigated by FT-IR spectroscopy using CDCl3 as probe molecule and Hammett acidity titration with n-butylamine and benzoic acid. Both the increase in the activation temperature and the decrease in Al content favored the increase in the basicity of Mg,Al-LDH. The nature of “Mn+ O2− Lewis acid-base” pairs was a key factor to control the catalytic behavior of the solids. The length of the M-O bond, the basicity of the oxygen ion and the strength of the metal ion on the surface affected the catalytic activity of the solids and their isomer selectivity in the reaction between methanol and propylene oxide to form 1-methoxy-2-propanol. It was demonstrated that brucite(150) can be applied as catalyst for at least four successive cycles without loss of activity. Keywords Brucite Mg,Al-layered double hydroxides Basicity Propylene glycol methyl ether Propylene oxide 1 Introduction Nowadays, propylene glycol methyl ether is widely used as pollution-free solvent in fine chemicals synthesis in pharmaceutical, chemical and cosmetic industry [1]. One of the traditional methods for the synthesis of propylene glycol ethers is the reaction of propylene oxide (PO) with methanol: Remarkably, the nature of the catalyst allows to control the product distribution [2–5]. 1-methoxy-2-propanol (II) is predominantly formed in the presence of basic type catalysts (NaOH [2], oxides [5–7], or amines [6,8]), while 2-methoxy-1-propanol (I) is formed in the presence of acid type catalysts (BF3, H2SO4) [2,9]. Natural hydrotalcite (HT) has the formula [Mg6Al2(OH)16]CO3·4H2O. The hydrotalcite-type structure can be viewed as derived from brucite (Mg(OH)2). The substitution of a certain amount of Mg2+ by Al3+ makes the layers to have positive charge (one charge by each substitution), which is compensated by the carbonate anions located in the interlayer region (one carbonate by each two substitutions). Hydration water is also located in the interlayer region. The optimal degree of substitution is 0.25 (one cation position from four), leading to a Mg/Al ratio of 3, exactly the ratio observed in natural hydrotalcite, although pure hydrotalcite phases can be obtained in the laboratory using substitution degrees between 0.20 and 0.33 (Mg/Al ratios between 4 and 2). This structure can be adopted by combinations of a large number of divalent (Mg, Ca, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, etc.) and trivalent (Al, Ga, In, V, Cr, etc.) cations, almost with the only condition that their size is not very different from that of Mg2+. By the presence of two cations in their composition, this family of compounds is also called Layered Double Hydroxides (LDHs). They are also called Anionic Clays, as their structure resembles that of smectitic clays, but with the layer charged positively and with compensating anions in the interlayer [10]. LDHs have been demonstrated as efficient and selective catalysts for the synthesis of glycol ethers [11–15]. Thus, in the presence of Zn,Mg,Al-catalysts derived from HT-like compounds the propylene oxide conversion of PO and selectivity towards (II) were 95.9% and 90.9%, respectively, under optimal reaction conditions (amount of the catalysts 1.8wt.%; molar ratio MeOH/PO 5:1; 120°C and 3h) [11]. Zeng et al. [15] reported the preparation of Mg,Al-LDHs with different Mg/Al molar ratios by the urea method and the investigation of their catalytic properties in the synthesis of propylene glycol methyl ether, finding the highest activity in the presence of Mg,Al-LDHs calcinated at 500°C for 7h. Activity of activated Mg,Al-LDHs depended on the Mg/Al molar ratio; the increase in Mg/Al molar ratio up to 4.0 favored the improvement of the catalytic activity (conversion of PO and selectivity towards (II)), then the catalytic activity dropped. This trend was explained by the dependence of the basicity and the crystallinity on the Mg/Al molar ratio. In optimal reaction conditions (Mg/Al=4.0, amount of the catalysts 0.9wt%, molar ratio MeOH/PO 4.0, 140°C, 6h) the conversion of PO and selectivity towards (II) were 93.2 and 97.4%, respectively. According to Manivannan et al. [16], catalysts based on Mg,Al-LDHs contained weakly basic OH groups, medium basic sites formed by MO pairs and strong basic surface sites formed by the isolated surface O2−. In our recent investigation of this reaction in the presence of M-PILCs (M=Al, Ga and Zr) [17] and metal phosphate molecular sieves [18], we have suggested that the reaction mechanism involves the interaction of reactants with active sites “Mn+ O2− Lewis acid-base” pairs. In the present work, two series of materials having the brucite or hydrotalcite-type structures were investigated as catalysts for the reaction of propylene oxide with methanol. The first series of materials were based on natural brucite from the deposit of Kuldur (Russian Mining Chemical Company, Moscow). The second series of materials were based on Mg,Al-LDHs with different Mg/Al molar ratio. As indicated before, Mg,Al-LDHs are related to brucite, resulting from the partial substitution of Mg2+ by Al3+, the change of chemical composition should change their acid-base properties and, therefore, the catalytic behavior. So, one of the purposes of this study was to demonstrate the potential application of brucite as heterogeneous catalyst in this reaction, and other purpose was to investigate how the changes from brucite to hydrotalcite influence on the catalytic behavior of the resulting solids. Acid-base properties have been studied by FT-IR spectroscopy using CDCl3 as probe molecule and Hammett acidity titration with n-butylamine and benzoic acid. Special attention will be paid to control reaction rate and selectivity towards (II) in the presence of these materials. Note that demonstrations of correlations between acid-base properties and catalytic activity of Mg,Al-LDHs are rather limited, while application of brucite as catalyst for this reaction is absent. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Propylene oxide (PO) and n-propanol were purchased from Aldrich. Commercial methyl alcohol was used without any further purification. Brucite came from the deposit of Kuldur (Russian Mining Chemical Company, Moscow). Brucite was dried/calcined at 90, 150, 250 or 400°C for 2h, and characterized and used as catalysts without further treatments. The samples were identified as Brucite(T), T being the temperature of drying/calcination, in °C. Mg,Al-LDHs were prepared according to the method described in [19,20]. The method involved the slowly mixing of the appropriate amounts of aqueous solutions X M of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and Y M of Al(NO3)3·9H2O (X + Y =1mol/l) with a 1M solution of NaOH and 0.1M of Na2CO3 at 120°C under vigorous stirring (the pH between 8 and 10) to yield an amorphous gel, followed by crystallization at 120°C. Theoretical ratios Mg/Al of 1.08, 2.57, 4.26 and 6.14 were targeted (Table 1 ). The precipitate was washed by water until absence of nitrates, and then dried at 150°C. The samples were identified considering their Mg/Al ratios determined from chemical analyses, as indicated in Table 1. 2.2 Instrumental measurements The porous structure of the materials was studied from nitrogen (Air Liquide, 99.999%) adsorption at −196°C using a static volumetric apparatus (Micromeritics ASAP 2010 adsorption analyser). All samples (0.2g) were degassed for 24h at 200°C at a pressure lower than 0.133Pa. The specific surface area (SBET) was calculated from the adsorption data over the relative pressure range between 0.05 and 0.20. The total pore volume (Vp) was calculated from the amount of nitrogen adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.99. The micropore volume (Vμp) and the external specific surface area (Sext) were calculated using the t-plot method, and the pore diameter applying the BJH method. The chemical analyses of the solids were carried out by means of inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES). The X-ray diffraction patterns from random samples were collected on а X-ray diffractometer (Ultima-IV, Rigaku), acquired as part of the Moscow State University Development Program, using Cu-Kα radiation (λ=1.54056Å), rapid detector D/Tex-Ultra, scan range 3.6–65° 2θ, scan speed 5°/min, step 0.02° 2θ, maximum intensity ∼25000 counts. Quantative mineral analysis has been done by Rietveld full-pattern fitting method [21]. The DR-UVvis spectra were recorded on a UV-2501 PC Shimadzu spectrometer with an IRS-250A accessory in the 190–900nm range with a resolution of 2nm; BaSO4 was used as standard reference. The basicity of Mg,Al-LDHs was determined by the method of indicator titration with 0.01M benzoic acid in benzene. Mg,Al-LDHs were calcinated at 150°C for 1h. Calcined barium oxide was used as a comparison standard. Bromothymol blue (pKa =7.2), dinitroaniline (pKa =15.0), 4-chloro-2-nitroaniline (pKa =17.2), 4-chloroaniline (pKa = 26.5) are used as indicators. The concentration of acid sites was determined by the method of indicator titration with butylamine in benzene. Basicity of brucite was studied by IR spectroscopy using CDCl3 as probe molecule. The analysis method was described in [22]. The strength of the base sites was estimated using the following equation: log νC-D =0.0066 PA −4.36 (1) where νC-D is the shift, in cm−1, of CD vibration and PA is the proton affinity. IR spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu FTIR–8300S spectrometer in the range between 400 and 6000cm−1 with a resolution of 4cm−1. 2.3 Catalytic test Brucite and LDHs were tested in the synthesis of 1-methoxy-2-propanol from methanol and propylene oxide (PO) at 120 and 140°C. PO (99.5%) was purchased from Acros Organic. Commercial methanol was used without any further purification. The reaction was carried out in a stainless steel autoclave reactor with an inner volume of 25cm3. The standard procedure was as follows: 7.4mmol PO, MeOH (MeOH/PO=8mol/mol) and catalyst (3wt.%) were introduced into the autoclave. After running at 120 or 140°C for 1 or 7.5h under magnetic stirring, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature. The products were analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7820) with a flame ionization detector on a HP-5 capillary column, after separation by centrifugation of the catalysts. n-Propanol was used as the internal standard to calculate the amount of the products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical and textural properties of the catalysts 3.1.1 Characterization of brucite Chemical composition of natural brucite was (wt.%): 38.3% Mg, 0.03% Al and 0.005% Na. Its X-ray diffractogram (Fig. S1, Supporting information) pointed out that it mainly consisted on brucite (89.5%), identified by the diffraction peaks at 4.77, 2.72, 2.37, 1.79, 1.57 and 1.49Å. Moreover, it contained impurities of dolomite (2.4%, diffraction peak at 2.89Å), calcite (1.4%, diffraction peak at 3.03Å), magnesite (0.8%, diffraction peaks at 2.72 and 2.11Å), lizardite (1.5%, diffraction peaks at 7.32, 4.60, 3.65, 2.62, 2.50, 2.34 and 2.15Å), and traces of smectite (diffraction peaks at 13.6, 6.5, 4.45 and 2.19Å). Heating of brucite at 90–400°C led to its dehydration, and only at 400°C the phase change from brucite to MgO – periclase was completed, this phase being characterized by the diffraction peaks at 2.11 and 1.50Å. The mineralogical impurities remained practically unchanged, as carbonates and silicates decompose at higher temperatures. IR spectra of brucite activated at several temperatures in the region of hydroxyl stretching vibration are shown in Fig. S2A (Supporting information). The spectrum of natural brucite showed an intense band at 3697cm−1 that can be attributed to hydroxyl stretching vibration [23,24]. Moreover, the bands at 3649 and 3625cm−1 can be attributed to the stretching vibration of MgOH groups (Table S1, Supporting information). The intensity of all these bands slightly decreased after calcination of sample at 90°C for 2h, while calcination at higher temperature led to its sharp decrease. Note that bands at 3763 and 3798cm−1 can be revealed in the spectrum of brucite, which can be assigned to AlOH groups due to the presence of a small amount of Al in brucite (0.3wt.%). Moreover, bands from carbonate groups in the region of 3200–3700cm−1 are also observed in the spectrum (Fig. S2A, Table S1, Supporting information). The intensity of these bands decreases with increasing the temperature of calcination of brucite. The low frequency bands in the IR spectra of brucite activated at several temperatures are shown in Fig. S2B (Supporting information). Bands were observed close to 964cm−1 (high-frequency MgOH angle-bending mode), 1018cm−1 (normal modes for MgOH interactions), at similar positions that in the IR spectrum of brucite [23]. Bands at 798, 1018 and 1080cm−1 may be attributed to the presence of traces of smectite. Bands at 853, 881, 1429 and 1489cm−1 were assigned to the presence of calcite, dolomite or magnesite [23]. The decrease in intensity of these bands with calcination of sample suggested the beginning of the decomposition of the carbonates. The effect of the temperature on the textural properties is also clear and confirms the results found with other techniques (Table 2 ). Up to a temperature of 250°C, no appreciable changes are observed in the specific surface area and pore volume, obtaining values of 15m2/g and 0.054cm3/g. However, these values increase significantly after treatment at 400°C, obtaining 270m2/g and 0.215cm3/g. The thermal treatment produces a phase change from brucite to MgO-periclase that is confirmed by the type of adsorption isotherm, from type II–III to type I–II (see Fig. S3, Supporting information). The phase change is also confirmed from the modification of the C constant, related to the interaction adsorbate-adsorbent. The increase of C from 82 to 170 could be related to the dehydration process. The phase change can affect strongly this type of interaction, decreasing C up to 38. 3.1.2 Characterization of Mg,Al-LDHs The X-ray powder diffraction patterns of Mg,Al-LDHs are shown in Fig. S4 (Supporting information). All diffractograms were typical for solids having the hydrotalcite structure (JCPDS-14-191). Although nitrates were the source of the cations, as sodium carbonate was used in the synthesis, it was expected that carbonate was the interlayer anion, due to the strong preference of this anion for the interlayer region. The characteristic reflections were observed in the low angle region (2θ<25°), the middle angle region (2θ=30°−50°) and the high angle region (2θ=55°−65°), assigned to sharp and intense basal 00 l reflections of 003 and 006 planes, broad 0kl reflections of 012 and 015 planes, and sharp hk0 and hkl reflections of 110 and 113 planes, respectively [16,26–28]. Very crystalline solids are obtained in the cases of Mg,Al-LDH(3.89) and, especially, Mg,Al-LDH(2.63), and less crystalline in the cases of Mg,Al-LDH(0.62) and Mg,Al-LDH(1.50), which agrees with the fact that the first two solids show Mg/Al ratios in the range allowed for the formation of hydrotalcite structure while the last two solids are out of this range (as hydrotalcite formally derives from brucite, low amounts of Al do not allow the formation of pure hydrotalcite, while high Al amounts provoke repulsion between Al-containing octahedra, distorting the structure). In fact, for solids Mg,Al-LDH(0.62) and Mg,Al-LDH(1.50), although low-crystalline hydrotalcite is the only phase observed, their chemical composition indicates that an excess of amorphous alumina may also exist. The observed reflections can be indexed in a three-layer 3R polytype with rhombohedral symmetry (space group R3m). The values of the lattice parameters, a and c , calculated from 00 l reflections of 110 and 003 planes ( c =3d 003 and a =2d 110) are shown in Table 3 . The basal spacings varied between 7.54 and 7.80Å, with the experimental Mg/Al ratio, so being related to the charge of the layers and consequently to the amount of compensating interlayer carbonate anions, the increase in the Al content led to the decrease in the basal spacing between the layers d 003 and the lattice parameters, a and c . The decrease in the basal spacing implied a parallel decrease of the distance between layers, h , when increasing the Al content in the solids (Table 3). This trend can be explained by the higher electrostatic attraction between the positive hydroxide layers and negative interlayers when increasing the Al content [27,28]. The distance between the layers was calculated using the following equation: h = d 003 −4.8 (2) where 4.8Å is the thickness of the brucite-like layer. Moreover, the experimental data pointed out that the variation of the Al content affected both the crystallinity and the lattice strain of Mg,Al-LDHs. Thus, according to the intensity and width of (003) reflection, the increase in the Al content led to the decrease in the crystallinity of samples and, moreover, to the decrease in the unit cell dimension. First of all, this phenomenon can be explained by the difference in size of metal ions, i.e. the size of Al3+ (0.0535nm) is much smaller than Mg2+ (0.072nm). This difference can lead to the strong interaction of trivalent cations with OH groups compared to divalent cations, i.e Al3+ cations in the brucite-like layers of Mg,Al-LDHs attracted the OH groups more strongly than Mg2+ cations, what favored the changing of the average a lattice parameter (Table 3). This effect has been demonstrated for Mg,Al-LDHs [29,30] and Mg,Fe-LDHs [31]. The textural properties of Mg,Al-LDHs also depended on the Al content. As can be seen from Table 3 specific surface area and pore volume rose with increase in Al content in Mg,Al-LDH. This may be due to the presence in these samples of alumina, with high specific surface area, and not detected in the diffractograms by its amorphous nature. The disorder in the interlayer spacing of Mg,Al-LDHs has been also followed from IR spectra (Fig. S5, Supporting information). The spectra clearly showed the relatively broad carbonate modes at 670cm−1 (ν 4), 880cm−1 (ν 2), 1050–1069cm−1 (ν 1), and that the relatively broad carbonate ν 3 mode at around 1380cm−1 split into two bands 1368 and 1398cm−1 [25,32,33]. The mode ν 1 of carbonate is not active in IR, so its activation indicates that it has low symmetry, as also suggested by the splitting of ν 3 mode, due to the location of this anion in the interlayer. The shift of ν 1 mode from 1069cm−1 in the spectrum of Mg,Al-LDH(0.61) to 1050cm−1 in the spectrum of Mg,Al-LDH(0.86) pointed out to the decrease of the trivalent cation in the brucite layer [34]. 3.1.3 Basicity of brucite and Mg,Al-LDHs The change of the basicity of brucite as a function of the activation temperature and of Mg,Al-LDHs depending on their composition was investigated by IR spectroscopy using CDCl3 as probe molecule. The spectra of CDCl3 adsorbed on brucite activated at 90, 150, 250 and 400°C are shown in Fig. S6A (Supporting information). For brucite activated at 90°C, three bands at 2211, 2237 and 2252cm−1 can be disclosed in the spectrum after deconvolution. At the same time, bands at 2210–2212, 2230–2232 and 2245–2247cm−1 were observed in the spectra of the solids heated at 150, 250 and 400°C. The positions of the bands in these spectra are given in Table S2 (Supporting information). All these bands can be assigned to the interaction between CDCl3 and basic sites. According to Paukshtis et al. [35], bands in the region of 2210–2220cm−1 are the result of the interaction of CDCl3 with an oxygen atom through a proton (Cl3C-D→O), while bands in the region of 2230–2260cm−1 are due to the interaction of CDCl3 with OH groups. This assertion is in agreement with our experimental data. The position of the bands at 2210–2212cm−1 did not change with increasing of temperature activation of brucite, while bands at 2252 and 2237cm−1 shifted to 2245–2247 and 2230–2232cm−1, respectively (Fig. S6, Table S2, Supporting information). Unfortunately, the nature of bands at 2210–2212cm−1 was not clear. Bands in the regions of 2240–2260cm−1 (2252 and 2245cm−1) and 2220–2240cm−1 were likely to arise from interaction between CDCl3 with basic sites on the brucite layer. The strength of these basic sites was estimated from the shift of ν C-D using Eq. (1) [35]. The values for the proton affinity (PA) are presented in Table S2 (Supporting information). It was deduced that the increasing of the activation temperature from 90 to 150°C was accompanied by the increase of the strength of two basic sites of brucite (PA) from 843 and 886kJ/mol to 867 and 900kJ/mol, respectively. The further increasing of activation temperature did not affect the strength of the basic sites. IR spectra of CDCl3 adsorbed on Mg,Al-LDHs activated at 400°C are shown in Fig. S6B (Supporting information). After deconvolution, three bands at 2210–2212, 2220–2235 and 2247–2250cm−1 can also be disclosed in all the spectra, their positions are listed in Table S2 (Supporting information). Only the position of the band in the region of 2220–2235cm−1 depended on the Mg/Al atomic ratio, shifting from 2235 to 2220cm−1 when Mg/Al increased from 0.61 to 4.00. At the same time, the increase in Mg/Al from 0.61 to 4.00 led to a parallel increase of the strength of the basic sites from 884 to 915kJ/mol (Table S2, Supporting information). According to Manivannan et al. [16], Mg,Al-LDHs possess three type of surface basic sites, namely the sites of weak (OH groups), medium (MO pairs), and strong (O2− anions) basicity. The surface concentration of weak and medium strength basic sites increased when decreasing the Al content. Therefore, the shift of the band in the region of 2220–2235cm−1 can point out the change of the nature of OH groups and MO pairs in Mg,Al-LDHs with the variation of Al content. Other approach for the estimation of the change of the nature of OH groups and MO pairs in Mg,Al-LDHs with the variation of Al content is based on the “optical basicity”. According to Duffi and Ingram [36], the optical basicity characterizes the electron donor power of the catalyst lattice oxygen and depends on the cation(s) valence and coordination. Lebouteiller and Courtine [37] demonstrated that optical basicity can be calculated for any oxide or complex. Generally, the optical basicity (Λ) can be calculated using the following Eq. (3): ICP= aΛ+ b (3) where ICP is the so-called ionic-covalent parameter. Early [17], we have suggested to use the ICP parameter for the quantitative description of the acid-base properties of Al-, Zr- and Ga-containing pillared clays. ICP parameter takes into account both the type (ionic to covalent) of MeO bond and the extent (through polarizability) of the negative charge borne by oxygen, and is calculated by the following equation [38,39]: ICP=log P−1.38×χ+2.07 (4) where χ is the electronegativity (in Pauling-type units [40]) and P is the polarizing power of the cation (P= e/r 2, e – formal charge, r – Shannon ionic radius). Thus, the bulk parameter optical basicity Λ may be the most appropriate parameter for characterization of Mg,Al-LDHs, because this parameter takes into account both the type (ionic to covalent) of MeO bond and the extent (through polarizability) of the negative charge borne by oxygen, i.e. the actual coordination of each ion. The values of optical basicity for Mg,Al-LDHs were estimated by the following equation [38]: Λ=XMgΛMg +XAlΛAl (5) where XAl,XMg, ΛAl and ΛMg are the equivalent fractions of metals and optical basicity of Mg and Al, respectively. The main results are shown in Table 4 . The linear correlation between atomic ratio of Mg/Al and Λ is clearly observed in Fig. 1 A. Optical basicity rose when increasing the Mg/Al atomic ratio, i.e. with the decreasing of Al content. This trend was in agreement with the data obtained by IR spectroscopy using CDCl3 as probe molecule. Moreover, this correlation was also in agreement with the data determined by the method of indicator titration in benzene (Table 4, Fig. 1B), which indicated that Mg,Al-LDHs possessed both Brønsted acid sites (BAS) and basic sites (BS). The decrease in Al content in Mg,Al-LDHs favored the simultaneous decrease in the amount of BAS and the increase in BS. 3.2 Catalytic properties of brucite and LDHs The catalytic properties of brucite and the anionic clays were studied in the synthesis of propylene glycol methyl ethers from methanol and propylene oxide (PO). Special attention was focused on the relationships between chemical composition, basic properties and catalytic performance of the materials. The heterogeneous character of the reaction in the presence of brucite and Mg,Al-LDHs was confirmed in special experiments. Thus, brucite(150) catalyst was filtered off after 1h of the reaction at 120°C, 8mol/mol of MeOH/PO, 4.1wt.% of catalyst, where the conversion of PO was about 20%. Then, the filtrate without the catalyst was further stirred at 120°C for 3h in autoclave. After removing the catalyst, the change of conversion of PO (21%) was negligible. The catalytic behavior of brucite was investigated at 4.1wt.% of catalyst, 120°C and using a MeOH/PO molar ratio of 8; the results obtained are summarized on Table 2. The heating temperature of the catalysts affected the conversion of PO and the selectivity towards 1-methoxy-2-propanol (II). The increase in the heating temperature from 90 to 150°C led to a clear increase both in the conversion of PO (from 13 to 20%) and the selectivity towards (II) (from 72.0 to 87.7%), respectively (Table 2, Fig. 2 ). The heating of brucite at higher temperatures did not change these values. These changes in the catalytic behavior were parallel to the effect of the activation temperature on the basicity of brucite (Fig. 2 , Table S2, Supporting information). Similar trends were observed at 2.2wt.% of catalyst, 120°C and MeOH/PO molar ratio of 12 (Table 2). The catalytic behaviour of Mg,Al-LDHs in this reaction was also performed at 2.2wt.% of catalyst, 120°C and using a MeOH/PO molar ratio of 12. The amount of Al in the Mg,Al-LDH clearly affected the conversion of PO and the selectivity to the isomers (Table 2). The decrease in Al content led to the increase in the selectivity towards (II); thus, the increase in the Mg/Al atomic ratio from 0.61 to 4.00 rose the selectivity towards (II) from 53.5 to 84.6%. The highest selectivity towards (I) (36.4%) for Mg,Al-LDH(0.61) catalyst can be explained by the large amount of BAS sites in this solid (Table 4, Fig. 3 A). Our previous investigations on the catalytic properties of M-PILCs (M–Al, Ga and Zr) [17] and metal phosphate molecular sieves [18] allowed to suggest that the strength of the basic sites determined the isomer selectivity towards (II). This trend is now also observed for LDH catalysts, the increase in the strength of basic sites of Mg,Al-LDHs, i.e increase in Λ and PA, led to the rise in the selectivity towards (II) and the conversion of PO (Fig. 3B,C). The amount of Al in Mg,Al-LDH also conditioned the conversion of PO (Table 5 ). The increase in the Mg/Al atomic ratio from 0.61 to 4.00 ran parallel to the rise in the conversion of PO from 7 to 15%, which can be related to the increase in the amount of basic sites, as the ratio BS/BAS increased from 1.8 to 14.2 (Fig. 3 A). At the same time, the increase in the strength of the basic sites of Mg,Al-LDHs, i.e. increase in Λ and PA, led to the rise in the selectivity towards (II) and the conversion of PO (Fig. 3B,C). In our previous investigations, it was found that the strength of the basic sites also affected the reaction, but in the opposite direction; the increase in the strength of basic sites led to a decrease in the reaction rate both in the presence of M-PILCs (M–Al, Ga and Zr) [17] or of metal phosphate molecular sieves [18]. This observation can be explained in terms of the reaction mechanism, assuming that the active sites are “Mn+ O2− Lewis acid-base” pairs. The adsorption of MeOH on the active sites caused the formation of methoxide species via the dissociation of MeOH into methoxide ion and proton on Lewis-acidic and basic sites, respectively. Moreover, the interaction of PO with the active sites can also lead to the dissociative activation of PO: The increase in the strength of the basic sites should favor the activation of PO and methanol. However, a high basicity should lead to a strong stabilization of (A) and (B) species on the surface of the solid and, therefore, lead to a decrease in the reaction rate. However, our experimental data were not in agreement with these assumptions. So, it can be proposed that not only the basicity of the oxygen ion and the strength of the metal ion, as well as the length of the MO bond, were very important for the activation of the reactants and the following rearrangement of the intermediates, because the basicity of Mg,Al-LDHs can be characterized by the extent of negative charge on the oxygen atom. Comparing with XRD data (Table 3), it was found that the conversion of PO rose from 7 to 15% with the increasing of the values of the lattice parameters, a and c , from 3.038 to 3.058Å and from 22.62 to 23.40Å, respectively. It may be remarked that the importance of the length of the M-O bond can also be revealed in the methoxycarbonylation of ketones with dimethyl carbonate in the presence of oxides of Ca, Mg, La and Zr [7]. In spite of its strong basic sites, the activity of CaO (radius of Ca2+ is 0.100nm) was lower than that of MgO (radius of Mg2+ is 0.072nm). In our case the difference in size of metal ions (radius of Al3+ and Mg2+ are 0.0535 and 0.072nm, respectively) can also affect the reaction rate. The comparison between the isomer selectivity and activity of brucite and Mg,Al-LDHs is especially interesting. As observed in Table 5, the activity of Mg,Al-LDHs was lower than that of brucite, while selectivities towards (II) were close. For better comparison, the reaction was carried out using Brucite(150) and Mg,Al-LDH(3.89) catalysts, and under the same experimental conditions, temperature of reaction 140°C, 4.1wt.% of catalyst, MeOH/PO molar ratio of 12 and time of reaction 7.5h, finding conversions of PO of 42 and 28%, respectively. Higher conversion of brucite (150) (36%) compared with Mg,Al-LDH(3.89) (15%) was also observed at 2.2wt.% of catalyst and 120°C. This can be explained by the difference of the nature of “Mn+ O2− Lewis acid-base” pairs; the strength of medium and strong basic sites of Mg,Al-LDH(3.89) is higher (915 and 928kJ/mol) than that of Brucite(150) (900 and 927kJ/mol) (Table S2, Supporting information). Secondly, it can be assumed that the higher activity of Brucite(150) compared with Mg,Al-LDH(3.89) may be related to the difference in the surface basicities. Therefore, a necessary condition for high reaction rates and selectivity for (II) was the presence of “Mn+ O2− Lewis acid-base” pairs with the optimal combination of the length of the MO bond, the basicity of the oxygen ion and the strength of the metal ion on the surface of the solid. 3.3 Stability and efficiency of brucite and Mg,Al-LDH One of the important properties for application of catalysts is their stability in the reaction mixture. The stability of brucite(150) was investigated, and it was found that this sample can be used repeatedly without significant loss of catalytic activity during at least 4 catalytic cycles (Fig. 4 ). After each catalytic test, brucite(150) catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by simple filtration, washed with methanol, dried in air and activated at 150°C for 2h. The efficiencies of brucite and Mg,Al-LDH(3.89) were compared to those of Mg,Al-LDH, MgO and CaO catalysts reported in the literature [7,11,15]. Because experimental conditions are different, the comparison was made by estimation of their efficiency by means of the TOF numbers: T O F = Δ P O T i m e × W c a t a l y s t , ( m o l / ( h × g ) ) where Wcatalyst is the amount of catalyst and Time is the reaction time. Note that brucite and Mg,Al-LDH(3.89) were activated at 500°C for 3h, because Mg,Al-LDH, MgO and CaO catalysts reported in the literature were calcinated at 450–500°C before reaction. The main results are shown in Table 6 . In general, efficiencies of brucite and Mg,Al-LDH(3.89) are close to that of Mg,Al-LDH(Mg/Al=4/1). Conversion of PO in the presence of MgO and CaO is lower in comparison with brucite and Mg,Al-LDH(3.89), while their selectivities towards (II) are close. 4 Conclusions Natural brucite (Kuldur deposit, Russia) and Mg,Al-layered double hydroxides (Mg,Al-LDHs) with different Mg/Al atomic ratios were investigated as catalysts for the synthesis of propylene glycol methyl ethers from methanol and propylene oxide. Special attention was focused on the investigation of basic and catalytic properties of these materials. The acid-base properties of Mg,Al-LDHs were analyzed by Hammett acidity titration with n‐butylamine and benzoic acid, finding that the amount of acid and base sites can be tailored by the Al-content in the solids. The decrease in Al content led to the simultaneous increase in the amount of basic sites and the decrease in acid sites. The basic properties of the anionic clays were investigated by FT-IR spectroscopy using CDCl3 as probe molecule. The increasing of the heating temperature of brucite from 90 to 150°C increased its basicity, but the further increasing of the heating temperature did not affect the strength of the basic sites. Basicity rose with the increase in the heating temperature of brucite, while the decrease in Al content favored the increase in basicity of the LDHs. This result was in agreement with the data of optical basicity estimated by a semiempirical method. The investigation of the catalytic behavior of the catalysts pointed out that 1-methoxy-2-propanol (II) was the main product with 84–88% selectivity. The activity of brucite correlated well with the basicity, which depended on the heating temperature of brucite. The amount of Al affected the conversion of PO and the isomer selectivity to (II). In LDHs, the decrease in Al content led to the increase in the selectivity towards (II) and the conversion of PO. The nature of “Mn+ O2− Lewis acid-base” pairs was proposed to be a key factor to control the catalytic behavior of these solids. The length of the M-O bond, the basicity of the oxygen ion and the strength of the metal ion on the surface affected the catalytic activity of the solids and their isomer selectivity in the reaction studied. Brucite(150) can be used repeatedly without significant loss of catalytic activity during at least four catalytic cycles. The comparison of the efficiencies (TOF) of brucite and Mg,Al-LDH(3.89) activated at 500°C with Mg,Al-LDH(Mg/Al=4/1) reported in literature points that their TOF values are close. coredata.dc:description: The aim of this study was to investigate the correlation between the basic and catalytic properties of brucite and Mg,Al-layered double hydroxides (Mg,Al-LDHs) in the reaction of propylene oxide with methanol. The basic properties of the solids were investigated by FT-IR spectroscopy using CDCl3 as probe molecule and Hammett acidity titration with n-butylamine and benzoic acid. Both the increase in the activation temperature and the decrease in Al content favored the increase in the basicity of Mg,Al-LDH. The nature of “Mn+ O2− Lewis acid-base” pairs was a key factor to control the catalytic behavior of the solids. The length of the M-O bond, the basicity of the oxygen ion and the strength of the metal ion on the surface affected the catalytic activity of the solids and their isomer selectivity in the reaction between methanol and propylene oxide to form 1-methoxy-2-propanol. It was demonstrated that brucite(150) can be applied as catalyst for at least four successive cycles without loss of activity.
coredata.dc:title: Synthetic and natural materials with the brucite-like layers as high active catalyst for synthesis of 1-methoxy-2-propanol from methanol and propylene oxide
